task.title: Setting Up a Development Environment for Plugins

keywords.indexterm: Setting up a development environment for plugins

prereq.p: You will need a recent version of Eclipse EE.

context.p: This procedure describes a development environment that can be used to increase your productivity in writing plugins for .

Developing a plugin for might require repetitive code-testing cycles. Since the process of building a whole SDK project requires a full Maven build, the whole process might prove to be time consuming. The following procedure provide a faster alternative for testing the plugin:

step.cmd: Go to the following repository and follow the instructions: .
Run in a Tomcat server. You can either use one of the installation kits, or build it using the Oxygen XML SDK.

info.note: If you are using one of the installation kits, you should disable file security in order to work with plugins in development mode.

step.cmd: Look in the Tomcat logs (or in the console) for a line like "Loading plugins from: ${path}" and note the path of the plugins folder.
In the plugins folder, create a sub-folder with a name of your choice (for example, myplugin).
In that folder (myplugin), create a plugin.redirect file that contains the path to your plugin project (created in step 2) on a single line.
Import your plugin project in Eclipse.

substep.cmd: Browse for the location of your plugin.

step.cmd: Modify the plugin.xml file to add a library reference to the directory where Eclipse places the compiled output.
step.info: With the default setup of a Maven project, this step requires that you add the following element:<library name="target/classes/"/>

step.cmd: You can now open a document in the and it will automatically load your plugin.
step.info: Every time you make changes to the plugin sources, you will need to restart .

postreq.p: Once you are happy with the result, you need to add the plugin back in your SDK project and follow these instructions to perform a final testing of the project.
